titlestmt.subtitle: A Finding Aid to the Collection in the Library of Congress
titlestmt.author: Prepared by Manuscript Division Staff

controlnote.p: Converted to EAD3 : Encoded Archival Description (EAD), Version 3 : Release: 1.1.1 : Release Date: 2019-12-16. Validating against latest version of schema.

maintenanceevent.eventdescription: Converted from EAD 2002 to EAD 3 (Release 1.1.1) by ead3_converter_mfer.xsl : Michael Ferrando, Library of Congress.
Finding aid encoded by Library of Congress Manuscript Division

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Resident of Salem, Massachusetts. Letters, clipped signatures, and other autograph items of prominent American and a few British figures, chiefly of the nineteenth century.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The autograph collection of Sarah Stone of Salem, Mass., was given to the Library of Congress by Mrs. Ray Morris in 1962

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: An index to the collection was prepared circa 1965. The index was revised as part of a new finding aid in 2011.

separatedmaterial.head: Transfers
separatedmaterial.p: A map of the Peninsula between the York and James Rivers, Virginia, circa 1861-1865 have been transferred to the Library's Geography and Map Division where they are identified as part of the Sarah Stone Autograph Collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The status of copyright in the unpublished writings in the Autograph Collection of Sarah Stone is governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.).

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The Sarah Stone Autograph Collection is open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Manuscript Reading Room prior to visiting. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Container number, Sarah Stone Autograph Collection, Manuscript Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The autograph collection of Sarah Stone (fl. 1840) spans the years 1720-1962, with the latest autographed item dating from 1947. The collection contains letters, clipped signatures, and other signed items of prominent American and a few British figures, chiefly of the nineteenth century.

The collection originated with Henry Colman (1785-1849), a Unitarian clergyman and friend of the Stone family, who initiated it with the gift of nineteen items to Sarah Stone in the early 1840s. Colman had received the items mainly in the course of studying agricultural methods in this country and in Europe, including signed letters by George Washington and British General Augustine Prevost during the Revolutionary War. Colman‚Äôs correspondents include John Adams, Henry Clay, Edward Everett ( who in 1837 appointed him commissioner to make an agricultural survey of Massachusetts) Angelina Emily Grimk√©, Benjamin Silliman, James Madison, Daniel Webster, and Martin Van Buren.

Other persons represented include John Quincy Adams, James Buchanan, Benjamin F. Butler, John C. Calhoun, Albert Einstein, Ralph Waldo Emerson, Alexander Hamilton, Oliver Wendell Holmes, Thomas Jefferson, James Russell Lowell, Charles Eliot Norton, and Booker T. Washington. Some letters were received by Sarah Stone herself or by members of her family, who were sailors and ship owners of Salem, Massachusetts, during the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, active in trade with China, Sumatra, and the West Indies. Some were friends of the family of Washington Irving. There are references to Irving in their correspondence as well as one of the author‚Äôs letters and a page of a manuscript in his hand.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Papers
arrangement.p: This collection is organized chronologically and indexed alphabetically by writer according to a check list of cards received from the donor. Clipped signatures and autographs that are undated or lack the year of creation are grouped together alphabetically in an undated file at the end of the collection.

unittitle.date: 1903-1947, 1962, including a copy of a letter about the collection and typed transcriptions of other letters
